newsitem.title: ROMANIA: LOVESICK ROMANIAN LINKS FUTURE TO NATO DATE.
newsitem.headline: LOVESICK ROMANIAN LINKS FUTURE TO NATO DATE.

text.p: Romanians' political obsession that their country will be left out of the first wave of NATO expansion has even come to invade their love lives.
"Come to me on the first wave," ran the entry in the lonely hearts column of this week's edition of the satirical newspaper Academia Catavencu.
"I'll be here for you until we join NATO. But I may no longer be here for a second wave, that is, 20 years from now."

Romania is lobbying hard to win an invitation along with more advanced candidates Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic when the Alliance announces its first eastward expansion at a summit in Madrid in July.
Opinion polls show more than 80 percent of Romanians want their country to join NATO now rather than in a second wave of enlargement, which they fear might never come.
Virtually every day sees a new, impassioned spin-off from the campaign in eastern Europe's only Latin country.

Several hundred pro-NATO "revolutionaries", veterans of the 1989 uprising which ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, marched through central Bucharest towards the U.S. embassy on Thursday urging Washington to throw its weight behind Romania.
One private television channel has launched a lottery, with viewers buying tickets for the equivalent of less than $1 and answering questions related to Romania's NATO bid.
Winners are promised cash prizes, luxury cars and places on a cavalcade of buses bound for Madrid for the July summit.
